title: Psalms Chapter 60 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 60 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 60 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 60.

questions.question: Who is the psalmist mentioned in Psalms 60:1?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:1 mentions that this psalm is a Michtam of David.

questions.question: In Psalms 60:1, how many Edomites did Joab smite in the valley of salt?
questions.explanation: The verse states Joab smote twelve thousand of Edom in the valley of salt.

questions.question: According to Psalms 60:2, what has God done to the earth?
options: Made it tremble and broken it
questions.correctAnswer: Made it tremble and broken it
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:2 says, 'Thou hast made the earth to tremble; thou hast broken it.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 60:3 say God has made the people drink?
questions.explanation: The verse states that God made the people drink the wine of astonishment.

questions.question: Who is given a banner in Psalms 60:4?
questions.explanation: According to Psalms 60:4, God has given a banner to those who fear Him.

questions.question: Which hand is mentioned in Psalms 60:5 for saving the beloved?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:5 specifically asks for salvation with God's right hand.

questions.question: In Psalms 60:6, what will God divide?
questions.explanation: The verse states God will divide Shechem and mete out the valley of Succoth.

questions.question: Which region is called God's washpot in Psalms 60:8?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:8 says, 'Moab is my washpot.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 60:7, who is called the lawgiver?
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states 'Judah is my lawgiver.'

questions.question: Who is asked to bring the psalmist into the strong city in Psalms 60:9?
options: Who will lead me into Edom?
Who will protect me from enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: Who will lead me into Edom?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:9 asks, 'Who will bring me into the strong city? who will lead me into Edom?'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 60:11 states that help from man is ultimately vain.
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:11 says, 'for vain is the help of man.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 60:12 declares that through God we shall do valiantly and tread down our enemies.
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states reliance on God for victory over enemies.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 60:10 asks God if He will not go out with the armies.
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:10 questions God, who had not gone out with the armies.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 60:4: 'Thou hast given a banner to them that ______.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:4 reads, 'Thou hast given a banner to them that fear thee.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 60:8: 'Over Edom will I cast out my ______.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:8 states, 'over Edom will I cast out my shoe.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 60 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 60 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 60, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during difficult times?
options: God is displeased and has abandoned us forever
God’s help is vain and unreliable
Through God we shall do valiantly; He will tread down our enemies
We must rely solely on human strength to overcome trials
questions.correctAnswer: Through God we shall do valiantly; He will tread down our enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:12 teaches that through God we can act valiantly and He is the one who will defeat our enemies, encouraging trust in God's power during trials. This is supported by Psalms 60:11, which shows that human help is vain, and Psalms 60:10, where God is asked to come out with the armies.

questions.question: How does Psalms 60:1 teach us about humility and seeking God’s help when facing difficulties in life?
options: By boasting in our own strength
By acknowledging God’s displeasure and turning to Him again
By ignoring God and trusting only ourselves
By blaming others for our problems
questions.correctAnswer: By acknowledging God’s displeasure and turning to Him again
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:1 shows a humble recognition of God's displeasure and a heartfelt plea to turn back to Him, teaching us to seek God humbly when in trouble. This is reinforced by Psalms 60:2-3 discussing God’s discipline and the need for healing.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear in their spiritual walk. According to Psalms 60, what encouragement can you offer about God’s protection?
options: God gives a banner to those who fear Him to be displayed because of truth
God abandons those who are afraid
Fear is a sign of weak faith that God won’t help
We must hide from our enemies to be safe
questions.correctAnswer: God gives a banner to those who fear Him to be displayed because of truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:4 states that God provides a banner for those who fear Him, symbolizing His protection and truth, encouraging believers to trust and not be afraid. This aligns with the theme of God’s deliverance in Psalms 60:5 and 60:12.

questions.question: In the context of family life and leadership, what does Psalms 60:7 teach us about God’s authority and guidance?
options: Judah is the lawgiver appointed by God
Family leadership should be based on personal desires only
God has no role in family governance
Strength comes from human power alone
questions.correctAnswer: Judah is the lawgiver appointed by God
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:7 states that 'Judah is my lawgiver,' indicating God’s sovereign role in establishing leadership and law, teaching families to honor God’s authority in guidance. This is connected to the ownership and division of land mentioned in Psalms 60:6-8, symbolizing divine order.

questions.question: How does Psalms 60:11 teach us about humility and dependence on God in our work and daily efforts?
options: Help from man is vain; we must seek help from God
We can succeed without God’s help
Human effort is all that matters
Ignoring God’s guidance leads to success
questions.correctAnswer: Help from man is vain; we must seek help from God
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:11 recognizes that help from man is vain and calls for help from God, teaching humility and reliance on divine assistance in all endeavors. This complements Psalms 60:12 about doing valiantly through God.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and persistence can we learn from Psalms 60:5?
options: We should only pray when things are easy
We should earnestly ask God to save and hear us with His right hand
God never listens to our prayers
questions.correctAnswer: We should earnestly ask God to save and hear us with His right hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:5 asks God to save with His right hand and hear the prayer, encouraging believers to persistently seek God’s deliverance through prayer. This is consistent with the plea for God to turn to us again in Psalms 60:1 and 60:10.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 60, God’s people should rely primarily on human strength and wisdom to overcome their enemies.
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:11 states that help from man is vain and Psalms 60:12 affirms that through God we shall do valiantly, emphasizing reliance on God rather than human strength.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 60 reveals that even when God is displeased and judgment falls, believers should still turn to Him in faith and prayer.
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:1 openly acknowledges God’s displeasure but immediately calls for Him to turn to us again, encouraging believers to seek God’s mercy even in judgment. This theme is woven throughout the chapter.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 60:2 says, 'Thou hast made the earth to tremble; thou hast broken it: ____________; for it shaketh.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:2 calls upon God to 'heal the breaches thereof,' indicating a plea for restoration and healing after disruption, which teaches believers to seek God’s restorative power in times of brokenness.

questions.question: According to Psalms 60:3, what spiritual challenge does God allow His people to experience, and what can this teach us about perseverance?
options: God shows His people easy blessings only
God shows His people hard things and makes them drink the wine of astonishment
God abandons His people in hardship
questions.correctAnswer: God shows His people hard things and makes them drink the wine of astonishment
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:3 reveals that God allows His people to face hard things and bewilderment, which teaches us perseverance and trust amid trials, knowing God’s discipline has purpose. This connects with the call for God’s help in verses 1 and 11.

questions.question: How does Psalms 60:8 illustrate God's sovereignty and His relationship to nations, and what practical application does this have for Christian stewardship?
options: God owns Moab as a washpot and casts out Edom, showing His control over nations
God has no interest in earthly nations
Nations are independent of God’s will
God favors only one nation exclusively without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God owns Moab as a washpot and casts out Edom, showing His control over nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:8 uses imagery of God’s dominion over nations, teaching believers that God is sovereign over all and calls us to faithful stewardship under His authority. This relates to the division of land in verses 6-7.

questions.question: What does the question in Psalms 60:9 teach us about seeking God’s guidance when facing challenges?
options: Who will lead me into the strong city and Edom?
Who can succeed without God’s guidance?
Who will abandon us in battle?
Who will rely on their own power alone?
questions.correctAnswer: Who will lead me into the strong city and Edom?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:9 asks who will lead into the strong city and Edom, emphasizing the need to seek God’s guidance and leadership in difficult endeavors, teaching dependence on God’s direction.

questions.question: How can Psalms 60:6 encourage believers about God’s promises and provision in their personal and spiritual lives?
options: God rejoices and promises to divide and assign land to His people
God’s promises are only for the past
Believers should rely on themselves only
questions.correctAnswer: God rejoices and promises to divide and assign land to His people
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:6 shows God’s holiness and joy in giving His people their inheritance, which encourages believers to trust in God’s provision and faithful promises in their lives.

questions.question: In light of Psalms 60:10, how should believers respond when they feel God has withdrawn His presence in their struggles?
options: Plead with God to return and help them
Ignore God and rely on others
questions.correctAnswer: Plead with God to return and help them
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:10 shows a plea to God, who had seemingly cast them off, asking for His presence with their armies, teaching believers to persistently seek God’s help even when He seems distant.

questions.question: How does Psalms 60 teach the value of gratitude and contentment even in hardship?
options: By rejoicing in God’s holiness and His promises despite trouble
By complaining and resenting God during trials
By trusting only in human plans
questions.correctAnswer: By rejoicing in God’s holiness and His promises despite trouble
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:6 expresses rejoicing in God’s holiness and promises, while the whole chapter acknowledges hardship, teaching believers to remain grateful and content in God’s care amid difficulties.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 60 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 60.

questions.question: In Psalms 60:1, the psalmist refers to a battle involving which two Aram regions?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:1 explicitly mentions the conflict with Aramnaharaim and Aramzobah, indicating the geographical and political context of the psalm.

questions.question: What literary device is most evident in the phrase 'Thou hast made the earth to tremble; thou hast broken it' from Psalms 60:2?
questions.explanation: The two clauses in Psalms 60:2 show synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device where the second line restates the first.

questions.question: According to Psalms 60:3, what has God made the people drink?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:3 uses the metaphor 'wine of astonishment' to describe the hardship shown to the people.

questions.question: In Psalms 60:4, what has God given to those who fear Him?
questions.explanation: The verse states God gave a banner to those who fear Him so that it might be displayed because of the truth.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 60:5 asks God to save with His ______ hand.
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:5 specifically requests salvation with God's right hand, symbolizing power and deliverance.

questions.question: In Psalms 60:6, God promises to divide Shechem and mete out which valley?
questions.explanation: The verse reveals God's intention to apportion the valley of Succoth as part of His holy plan.

questions.question: What does Psalms 60:7 say about Gilead and Manasseh?
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares God's ownership over these territories as a sign of divine favor and authority.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 60:8 reflects a cultural practice of authority or ownership in the ancient Near East?
options: 'Over Edom will I cast out my shoe'
'Ephraim also is the strength of mine head'
questions.correctAnswer: 'Over Edom will I cast out my shoe'
questions.explanation: Casting a shoe over land symbolized claim or authority over a territory in the ancient Near East, as expressed in Psalms 60:8.

questions.question: Who does the psalmist ask to bring him into the strong city and lead him into Edom in Psalms 60:9?
questions.explanation: The rhetorical questions in Psalms 60:9 imply reliance on divine guidance for victorious entry.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 60:10, God went out with the armies of Israel during their battle.
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:10 states that God did not go out with the armies, indicating a sense of divine rejection or absence at that moment.

questions.question: What reason does Psalms 60:11 give for seeking help from God rather than man?
options: The help of man is vain
questions.correctAnswer: The help of man is vain
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes the futility of relying solely on human aid in contrast to divine assistance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 60:12 describe the victory achieved through God?
questions.explanation: The psalmist expresses confidence that through God, they will achieve courageous and decisive victory.

questions.question: Which tribal role is ascribed to Judah in Psalms 60:7?
questions.explanation: Judah is described as the lawgiver, highlighting its leadership and judicial role among the tribes.

questions.question: The expression 'Moab is my washpot' in Psalms 60:8 is an example of what type of literary device?
questions.explanation: Calling Moab a 'washpot' metaphorically indicates subservience or humiliation, reflecting Israel’s dominance.

questions.question: Which New Testament theme is foreshadowed by the psalmist's request for divine help and victory in Psalms 60:12?
options: The establishment of the kingdom of heaven
The role of the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: The psalm’s emphasis on divine empowerment anticipates New Testament teachings on faith enabling spiritual victory.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 60 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 60 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 60, what does God do to the earth as described in verse 2?
options: He makes it tremble and breaks it
questions.correctAnswer: He makes it tremble and breaks it
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:2 states that God has made the earth to tremble and broken it. This demonstrates God's sovereign power over creation, consistent with verses like Nahum 1:5 and Hebrews 12:26 where God's power causes the earth to shake.

questions.question: In Psalms 60:3, the people are described as drinking what symbolic 'wine'?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:3 describes God's people as drinking the wine of astonishment, symbolizing suffering or overwhelming trials. This echoes themes in Isaiah 51:17 and Revelation 14:10 where wine represents judgment and trial.

questions.question: What does God give to those who fear Him according to Psalms 60:4?
options: A banner to be displayed because of the truth
questions.correctAnswer: A banner to be displayed because of the truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:4 speaks of God giving a banner to those who fear Him for the display of truth. This banner symbolizes God's protection and presence, similar to Exodus 17:15 and Isaiah 59:19 where God’s name or banner signifies deliverance.

questions.question: In Psalms 60:6-7, which territories does God claim as His?
options: Shechem, Succoth, Gilead, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem, Succoth, Gilead, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Judah
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 clearly state that God will divide Shechem and Succoth, and claims Gilead, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Judah as His, indicating divine sovereignty over Israel. This is consistent with God's covenant promises in Genesis 15 and Joshua 1.

questions.question: What is symbolized by God casting out His shoe over Edom in Psalms 60:8?
options: Taking possession or dominion over Edom
questions.correctAnswer: Taking possession or dominion over Edom
questions.explanation: In Psalms 60:8, casting out a shoe symbolizes taking possession or asserting authority, as seen in Ruth 4:7-8 and Deuteronomy 25:9. This act signifies God's sovereign claim over Edom.

questions.question: According to Psalms 60:9, what is the psalmist's request regarding entering the strong city and Edom?
options: Who will bring me into the strong city and lead me into Edom?
Who will destroy the strong city and conquer Edom?
Who will bless the strong city and protect Edom?
Who will ignore the strong city and Edom?
questions.correctAnswer: Who will bring me into the strong city and lead me into Edom?
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:9 poses a question seeking divine guidance or deliverance into the strong city and Edom, reflecting dependence on God’s leading, consistent with Psalm 121:8 and Isaiah 41:13.

questions.question: What does the psalmist remind God of in Psalms 60:10?
options: That God had cast them off and did not go out with their armies
That God had blessed their enemies
That God had forgotten His covenant
That God had made them kings
questions.correctAnswer: That God had cast them off and did not go out with their armies
questions.explanation: In verse 10, the psalmist reminds God of His displeasure and absence in battle, emphasizing human dependence on divine presence, paralleling Exodus 33:3 and 1 Samuel 17:37.

questions.question: What reason does Psalms 60:11 give for seeking help from God instead of man?
options: The help of man is vain
Man is more powerful than God
questions.correctAnswer: The help of man is vain
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:11 teaches that help from man is futile, therefore God’s help is necessary. This theological truth aligns with Psalm 118:8 and Jeremiah 17:5 emphasizing reliance on God rather than human strength.

questions.question: According to Psalms 60:12, through whom do we do valiantly and tread down enemies?
questions.explanation: Verse 12 affirms that victory and valor come through God who enables us to overcome enemies, consistent with 2 Chronicles 20:15 and Ephesians 6:10 where divine power is foundational for triumph.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'banner' given to those who fear God in Psalms 60:4 regarding ecclesiology?
options: It represents the visible sign of God’s truth and protection over His people
It is a literal flag used in battle only
It signifies political authority over nations
It is a symbol of isolation from others
questions.correctAnswer: It represents the visible sign of God’s truth and protection over His people
questions.explanation: The banner in Psalms 60:4 symbolizes God’s truth and protection, an emblem of divine presence among the community, reflecting the church's identity under Christ as seen in Isaiah 59:19 and Revelation 7:2.

questions.question: In Psalms 60, how is God's holiness described in relation to His promises in verse 6?
options: God speaks in His holiness with rejoicing and promises to divide territories
questions.correctAnswer: God speaks in His holiness with rejoicing and promises to divide territories
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows God speaking in holiness, rejoicing, and declaring His sovereign distribution of land, emphasizing the sacredness and faithfulness of God's promises, consistent with Isaiah 6:3 and Hebrews 12:10.

questions.question: What theological theme is underscored by the psalmist’s plea in Psalms 60:1 that God turn to them again?
options: The need for divine restoration after judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The need for divine restoration after judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 60:1 expresses a plea for God’s return after having cast them off, reflecting the biblical theme of repentance and restoration after judgment (cf. Joel 2:13, Lamentations 5:21).

questions.question: How does Psalms 60 describe the relationship between God’s wrath and salvation?
options: God’s displeasure leads to discipline but also calls for deliverance
God’s wrath means eternal rejection without hope
God’s salvation is unrelated to His judgment
God’s wrath only applies to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: God’s displeasure leads to discipline but also calls for deliverance
questions.explanation: The psalmist acknowledges God's displeasure (v.1) but simultaneously pleads for salvation (v.5), illustrating the balance of divine judgment and mercy, consistent with Romans 11:22 and Hebrews 12:6.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most emphasized by the psalmist’s confidence in victory in Psalms 60:12?
questions.explanation: Verse 12 emphasizes that through God’s power we achieve victory over enemies, highlighting God’s omnipotence. This is consistent with Isaiah 40:29-31 and Ephesians 3:20.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Moab is my washpot' in Psalms 60:8 imply about God's relationship to Moab?
options: God views Moab as a vessel for cleansing His feet, symbolizing subjugation
God honors Moab as His chosen nation
God has no dealings with Moab
questions.correctAnswer: God views Moab as a vessel for cleansing His feet, symbolizing subjugation
questions.explanation: In verse 8, 'washpot' signifies a lowly object used for cleansing, indicating Moab's subjugated status before God, paralleling imagery in Ezekiel 25:10-11 and Deuteronomy 2:9.
